div1.head: Jim to Mademoiselle Marcelle Guerin May 6th 1916
div1.p: Thanks for your letter and the many compliments. Don’t fool yourself about what I’m going to do for I do not share your confidence in my ability.

With us the war is still going on in its rentless [sic] way, and to make things worse the coal at the thermal baths is running short and one is forced to take only a lukewarm bath now and then. The social features are improving. Cowden was decorated with the Midaille Militaire and we had a big review at the field. One of our drivers was killed with a bomb a Boche dropped and we gave him the sportiest funeral seen around these parts in years. To morrow we’re to have another joy ride thru [sic] the Val d’Ajol to attend the funeral of a Captain of a near by escadrille who was killed owing to his motor stopping. Cowden has beat it back to Paris before the lustre [sic] of his Midaille is dimmed and Prince who has just returned is going back. From all this you will know that our Babies have not been born. Five have arrived only so
Chapman, Cowden, Prince and I are without. Kiffin did well yesterday. He was trying out his machine and while in the air a terrific ground wind came up. Two Farmers standing on the field were blown over and wrecked but Kiffin managed to come down in a skilful [sic] way and landed. Mechanics immediately grabbed his machine to keep it from being blown away.

Rosa is still as pretty as ever. But have I told you about Rosa? She is of Italian birth but raised in France. For charm of manner, grace of figure, and beauty of face she can give them all a head start and then beat in a walk. Rosa serves beer in a home like cafe on the hill, and unless they make her stop I’m going to become a beer drinker. She has the trimmest ankles I’ve seen in ages and it mellows the beer to watch her walk towards one with it. The only draw back is that Rosa’s people never let her out of sight and so I have to talk with the family and say “Bonjour Coco” to the parrot.

To morrow the five that are ready will go over the lines so we’re really getting started. Bill Thaw
asked about you and sends his best regards.
I received a letter from Betty’s mother telling me her daughter had improved remarkably in the three days before writing and they hoped soon to move her to Paris.
I’m sorry you’ve been feeling badly. You’ve had a tough time of it this year.

Well I hope that I’ll get my plane in a few days and can get to work. This lazy life of Luxeuil [sp?] is getting on my nerves. As a summer resorter I’m enjoying myself tho [sic]. The town has Paris looking like a place of which the late Anthony Comstock might be mayor.
Walter Lovell wants to get into aviation and I’m giving him the information. Hope he does join for I know he’ll make good.
Must hurry along now and drink my afternoon’s cup of Luxeuil hot water.

closer.seg: Escadrille N. 124 Luxeuil My best to your Hte Saone. mother and father.
